comments.author: mh+mozilla@glandium.org
comments.text:
This came up in my mind during MozCamp, and would be helpful for the dozens developers wasting their time setting up a compiling environment, figure out compiling issues, and compiling Gecko when all they want is to modify frontend code in xul, js, css, xhtml, you name it.

One thing I mentioned to Paul Rouget that helps already is for them to use --enable-chrome-format=symlink, which avoids some rebuilds, though it doesn't cover preprocessed files.

Here is what i think we should have to help them stop wasting that time, which would also help getting more people hacking on the frontend:
- A --with-application=directory argument to configure, taking the directory to an existing build.
- From that directory content guess a relevant value for MOZ_CHROME_FILE_FORMAT and MOZ_BUILD_APP, or rely on what was given as configure arguments.
- Skip all configure checks that are only relevant to compiling, which means, basically, everything (including compiler checks) except the checks for zip and python, and maybe a couple other things.
- The "build" itself would only build/install chrome, resources, js components and JSMs, and copy the application files from the application directory given to --with-application to the relevant $DIST subdirectories.
